results.title: At 6 Catskills Resorts: Retro Design, Modern Comfort and Games, Lots of Games
results.abstract: Lodgings in this bucolic region north of New York City are targeting a new generation of visitors with organized “experiences,” nostalgic style elements and serious cocktails.

media.caption: Kenoza Hall in Kenoza Lake, N.Y., is housed in what was once a boardinghouse. Inside, guests will find modern comforts and Victorian ambiance.

results.title: A Tragedy in Omaha

results.adx_keywords: Longevity;Chromosomes;Cancer;Tumors;Heart;Genetics and Heredity;Research;New England Journal of Medicine
results.title: Link Between Long Telomeres and Long Life Is a Tall Tale, Study Finds
results.abstract: The longer a person’s telomeres, researchers found, the greater the risk of cancer and other disorders, challenging a popular hypothesis about the chromosomal roots of vitality.

media.caption: Harriet Brown, one of the study participants, has a number of cancer-related ailments and is tested regularly, but “there is really not much I can do at this point,” she said, because there is no way to prevent more tumors.
media.copyright: Andrew Mangum for The New York Times

results.adx_keywords: French Food (Cuisine);Pastries;Restaurants;Bakeries and Baked Products;South Korea
results.title: The South Korean Chefs Redefining the Art of Pastry
results.abstract: Their boundary-blurring desserts reflect their Korean background and French training.

media.caption: “I can say it’s very representative of my style,” Mrs. Ki said. “Very classic French dessert, but I make it my own style with Korean ingredients.”
media.copyright: Peter Flude for The New York Times

results.title: Why Americans Feel More Pain
results.abstract: Chronic pain is not just a result of car accidents and workplace injuries but is also linked to troubled childhoods, loneliness, job insecurity and a hundred other pressures on working families.

media.caption: When Bobbie Wert feels pain coming on, she repeats to herself, “It’s not so bad.”
media.copyright: Photographs by Ricardo Nagaoka for The New York Times

results.adx_keywords: Interior Design and Furnishings;Floors and Flooring;Fads;Color
results.title: Gray Floors Elicit Visceral Reactions. So Why Are They Seemingly Everywhere?
results.abstract: Fueled by social media, a hatred for trendy gray flooring is thriving. But for many people, living with gray floors isn’t a choice.

media.caption: Gray floors have been a source of vitriol for many people who have expressed their distaste on social media with posts that have frequently gone viral.
media.copyright: Jennilee Marigomen for The New York Times

results.byline: By Alexandra Alter and Elizabeth A. Harris
results.title: Asked to Delete References to Racism From Her Book, an Author Refused
results.abstract: The case, involving Scholastic, led to an outcry among authors and became an example of how the culture wars behind a surge in book banning in schools has reached publishers.

media.caption: Maggie Tokuda-Hall declined Scholastic’s offer to license her book, “Love in the Library,” on the condition that she edit her author’s note to remove a description of past and present instances of racism.
media.copyright: Marissa Leshnov for The New York Times

results.title: Nothing Is Bigger Than Stephen Curry vs. LeBron James
results.abstract: Curry and James are meeting in the playoffs, perhaps for the last time. Together and apart, they have redefined a generation of basketball.

media.caption: Golden State’s Stephen Curry, left, and LeBron James of the Los Angeles Lakers, right, are facing each other in the playoffs for the fifth time in their careers, now in the Western Conference semifinals.

results.title: The ‘Devil Bird’ Lands in New York, With More Likely to Come
results.abstract: Anhingas, water birds with snakelike necks, have turned up in Prospect Park in Brooklyn and far upstate, a sign of shifting ranges for birds from the South.

media.caption: An anhinga, also known as the devil bird, spotted in Prospect Park last month.

results.adx_keywords: World War II (1939-45);Pilots;Veterans;Purple Heart (Military Decoration);Age, Chronological;Content Type: Personal Profile;audio-positive-nostalgic;audio-neutral-immersive;internal-sub-only
results.title: He Bombed the Nazis. 75 Years Later, the Nightmares Began.
results.abstract: Like most of his generation, John Wenzel returned from World War II with no interest in sharing memories. Just shy of his 100th birthday, he found he could no longer ignore the past.

media.caption: John Wenzel left college after the bombing of Pearl Harbor and became a pilot, flying 93 missions in Europe before he turned 21.
media.copyright: Michelle V. Agins/The New York Times

results.adx_keywords: Airports;Art;Advertising and Marketing;Conspiracy Theories;Rumors and Misinformation;internal-sub-only;Denver International Airport;Denver (Colo)
results.title: A Towering, Terrifying Demon Horse Isn’t Even the Weirdest Part
results.abstract: The Denver airport is a magnet for conspiracy theories — and a case study in the line between mass delusion and fun.

media.caption: “Mustang,” a 32-foot-tall sculpture by the artist Luis Jimenez that is also known as Blucifer, stands outside Denver International Airport. Some people wonder if it is actually the pale horse of the apocalypse (the one ridden by Death).
media.copyright: Benjamin Rasmussen for The New York Times

results.adx_keywords: Royal Families;Automobile Racing;Content Type: Personal Profile;internal-sub-only;Schonbrunn Palace (Vienna, Austria)
results.title: The Prince With No Throne
results.abstract: If the Austro-Hungarian Empire still existed, 25-year-old Ferdinand Habsburg would eventually be its ruler. Instead he’s a racecar driver.

media.caption: “I’m so proud of my family and what they’ve done,” said Ferdinand Habsburg, the heir apparent to the House of Habsburg-Lorraine. “But I get to live a different life.”
media.copyright: Lisa Edi for The New York Times

results.adx_keywords: Presidential Election of 2024;United States Politics and Government;High Net Worth Individuals;Content Type: Personal Profile;Ramaswamy, Vivek (1985- );Republican Party
results.title: The Smooth-Talking Republican Who Would Rule by Fiat
results.abstract: Vivek Ramaswamy, a long-shot 2024 contender, is lavishly wealthy and astoundingly confident. He also promises to exert breathtaking power in ways that Donald Trump never did.

media.caption: Vivek Ramaswamy, an entrepreneur and author, told a crowd in New Hampshire recently, “I’m in this race to take the America First agenda far further than Donald Trump ever did.”
media.copyright: Ahmed Gaber for The New York Times
